fields.description: As a cloud administrator I would like DNS to be available as a user facing service so the need for manually specified IP mappings is reduced.

comments.body: In case anyone was as confused as I am, this story is not about implementing Route53, but rather simply providing DNS service from systems running user-api services.

[~sjones] would you mind reviewing the changes? 
git show bc0d037c9e82b990b99da4fb804285d02f951b6a

I did manual testing and it seems to work, but wanted to confirm it is what it's meant to solve.
Here's the summary:
 -- created the service builder for DNS service so that it becomes part of UFS
 -- removed dns_listener_address_match and  dns.services.hostmapping 
 -- TopologyDnsResolver will use listener interface to determine which host address to return

Typically modules for a service are broken up into common, service and backend. In this case there is no stateful backend, so the modules should be:

* dns-common
* dns (for the service implementation)

Within the dns-common module we would put:

* DnsConfigurationMessages.groovy
* Dns.java

and in the dns (service implementation) module:

* DnsConfiguration.java
* DnsServiceBuilder.java
* DNSBootstrapper.java
* DNSControl.java

We already had the component identifier (Dns.java) so it may not make sense to move that from the msgs module, if that leaves a module (currently called dns-service) with one file then we may want to skip the new module entirely.

I'm not sure we can remove the address mapping functionality, it might be in use in some deployments. TopologyDnsResolver changes look good to me otherwise.

The current fix removed only 'dns.services.hostmapping' property. The topology resolver will simply use the arriving interface to determine which IP to resolve for a service name. 
When 'dns_listener_address_match' is not specified, DNS service (at UFS) will listen on ALL interfaces. When it is specified, the service will listen on the matching address, in addition to the local bind address. For the use-case topology in EUCA-9122, it is ok to leave the property empty.

IIRC one use case that was supported with DNS hostmapping was using an external DNS server that delegated to our DNS. In this configuration the interface used to query our DNS may not be the same one used by external cloud users. Not sure if this is an important use case.
[~sjones] ok -- sounds like we need to get the property back and have it override the default resolution when specified.
[~spark], I do not know if it is something we need to support, just wanted to bring it up for discussion.
[~sjones] Ok. I'll then leave it to [~viglesias] [~decker] [~lwade].

Good question. I don't think we see a typical need for such a use case (i.e. a different network for DNS) but of course it would be good to have that flexibility. So are we saying something like this (excuse the terrible drawing):

!screenshot-1.png!
[~lwade] Yep that's accurate and cute drawing.

One thing we need to test is how DNS zone delegation will work with the changes. 

Previously, upstream DNS delegates EUCA-managed subdomain(dns_domain property) to one CLC. Since multiple DNS service will run on UFS hosts, the upstream DNS' configuration should be changed so that multiple NS records are created for the UFS hosts as authoritative servers for the EUCA-managed subdomain.
